NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
The Faculty Development Committee sponsored two panel discussions on the fifth principle of the Learning Model: “Learners and teachers at BYU-Idaho love, serve, and teach one another” on February 12 and 13.  Afterwards, participants were asked to reflect on what they learned.  I have summarized these reflections around major themes.  Three of these themes are included in this article.  Additional comments about the panel discussions posted in a previous Faculty Voices article.

Steve Hunsaker


Ideas for First Days


I like the idea of using unusual questions for the "get to know each other" segment of the first day.

Nancy Hayes — English


I learned that pondering and thinking about how to frame the course during the first class can set an atmosphere of caring and concern and help students break down the barriers that may hinder their learning.

Susan Garbett — Nursing


I plan to go “swimming.” I doubt I will ever drag my class down to the pool, but I am going to explore more creative ways to introduce the subject and tear down barriers on the first day of class.

Craig Johnson — Mathematics


Working with “Failure”


One of the major obstacles I have to overcome in order to achieve true learning and teaching is the idea of the “right” answer. Instead of just memorizing what is “right” and “wrong”, we need to (as a class) seek to understand the reasons, observations, or research that supports why statements, ideas, or theories are generally accepted.

Kory W. Godfrey — Computer Information Technology


I learned the importance of valuing "wrong" answers from students. This is not to say that I should encourage students not to master a given subject; rather, as students are striving to comprehend, internalize, and apply principles with which they may be relatively unfamiliar or inexperienced, I should help them feel safe in communicating their understanding of the things they are learning, even if that understanding is not yet fully developed.

Shawn Dorman — Religion


We should try to find what is right about a student’s wrong answer.

David Collins — Chemistry


We should practice what we preach and not be afraid of failures in our teaching ideas — some will go well, others won’t. My father used to say, “You win or you learn—you never fail.” This is as true with us as it is with our students.

Ed Kumferman — Foreign Languages and Literatures


Teachers as Learners


Our teaching is energized — which blesses our students—when teachers have opportunities to learn from one another.

Karen Holt — English


Daniel Baird’s comments about not getting caught up in the method itself but constantly searching for the principles involved reminded me of the importance of seeking and developing the gift of discernment.

Ed Kumferman — Foreign Languages and Literatures


The greatest learning I came to after the brown bag discussion was that I love to learn from others! As I listened to the examples shared, I thought to myself, I can do that. I really like to hear how the same technique is used in different disciplines.

Lynda Hawkes — Teacher Education


I enjoyed the ideas that were shared, but I especially appreciated being reminded that it is not just about copying my colleagues’ great teaching ideas but the personal process of seeking improvement in my own teaching practice. Whether I need to build a greater degree of trust with my students or create a safer and more motivating environment, I need to rely on the Spirit as I continually seek ideas that will best serve my current students.

Jackie Nygaard — Mathematics
